Earkey, G-.C.B.................................Secretary. 1, The Cabinet had before them & draft resolution and Protocol for the Suppression of Slavery and theSlave Trade, drawn up by a departmental committee presided ovex1 "by the Chajfibellor of the Duchy of lancaster for submiseioa to the Temporary Commissionon Slavery, a&d if approved Sgr t&eaai to ha submittedto the Counoil of the League of Nations with a viewto its adoption by the Assembly (Paper C*P.345(25))aThe Cabinet agreed -That the draft Easo3,ution and Protocolshould be- sent to Sir IMvugard for his assistance on the temporary Cocmiission onSlavery- as an indication of british policy on the subject, 1[nation in.ierence:binet 345), Con-tislon 1. )2. At the request of the Secretary of State forForeign Affairs, the Cabinet agreed That a Cabinet Committee, composed as'follows.--The Prime Minister (In the Chair),The Secretary of State for ForeignAffairs,The Lord President of the Council,The Lord Privy Seal,The Secretary of state the Secretary of state the Secretory of state affairs and Secretary of Statefor the Colonies for India,for War,for Dominionshould meet the same afternoon in theLord Privy Seal's Room at the House ofLords, to assist the Foreign secretary in regard to certain political ques-tions relating to the Situation inChina. Q 9 Oeviousfersrtces:$blast 925); Conyfusion 2ibjIbinet 2425), Con-ausipn o, jl^^ehali Gardens. .S.W.1,july 15, 1925s The Cabinet had before them the Report of theNaval Programme Committee. In a brief covering note the Chairman (Lord Birkenhead) had explained that neither the First Lord of the Admiralty nor the Chan-oellor of the Exchequer had been asked to sign theReport, and with their concurrence he had invited only those members qf the Committee who were in an independ-ent position to add their signatures (Paper CP.-342(25)).The Cabinet heard a full exposition of the navaland financial aspects of the question from the FirstLord of the Admiralty and the Chancellor of theExchequer respectively.The Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs was asked to say whether recent events had led him tomodify the opinion given at the Committee of ImperialDefence and quoted In the Report of the Committee,"that,in existing circumstances, aggressive actionagainst the British Empire on the part of Japan withinthe next ten years is not a contingency seriously to beapprehended8.absoluteHie reply was that, while no/guarantee could beby any Ministergiven/as t.o the permanence of good relations with aparticular Power, or would be of any value If it wasgiven, on a review of the situation and after consulta-tion with his advisers at the "Foreign Office, he saw no reason to modify the above opinion-A discussion followed, in which, among others,the Chairman and other members of the Cabinet Committeetook part.rThe time at the disposal of the Cabinet did not enable them to complete the discussion, whach was adjourned until 11-30 a.rc on the following day.
